page.title: 18THE RIVER ANCHOLME
page.content: The{New River Ancholme}flows north for 3O kilometres from{Bishop's Bridge to{Ferriby Sluice}on the River Humber. It is, however, the{Old River Ancholme that winds its way into the western margin of our block and it was this river, once tidal before sluice gates were erected at South Ferriby, that posed the greatest difficulty to traffic travelling in an east-west direction. Brigg grew up on a tongue of firm ground where crossing was possible on foot and by cart. Until the l93O's{sailing barges}carried goods up and down the river and passengers before that. Today the river is a{drainage}channel taking water from the farm land on either side. It takes cleaned effluent from {Brigg Sugar Factory}and from the{ Sewage Works. }The river provides water for some of the
